Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2014 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Anand U. Oza is "Wave-Particle Coupling in Fluid Dynamics." The host institution for the fellowship is New York University, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Esteban Tabak.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The field of active matter has recently received substantial scientific attention from the applied mathematics, physics and engineering communities. While the physics of active systems driven by low-speed flows is relatively well-understood, many active systems generate long-lived and spatiotemporally complex flows, which are absent in conventional active matter systems. The PI's recent research has focused on fluid-structure interaction problems in active matter systems, with a focus on wave-particle coupling between active constituents.

The first project concerned the pilot-wave dynamics of bouncing droplets. In a remarkable series of experiments, Yves Couder and coworkers demonstrated that millimetric oil droplets bouncing on a vibrating fluid bath exhibit analogs of quantum mechanical phenomena, such as tunneling and orbital quantization. These walkers have recently attracted considerable interest from the scientific community, as they offer an intriguing visualization of wave-particle coupling on a macroscopic scale. The PI and his collaborators constructed and analyze an equation describing the motion of these "walkers." More recently, they extended the model to account for interactions between pairs of walkers. Through an iteration between experiment and theory, they discovered a new effect through which bound states of walkers are stabilized. This effect is crucial to mathematically modeling the walkers' collective dynamics, which is the subject of ongoing work. 

The PI's work on the walking droplet system provides a striking experimental and theoretical visualization of wave-particle interactions in a macroscopic system. The model of the walking droplet system furnished predictions that have since been confirmed experimentally, and has inspired a number of subsequent theoretical studies.

The second project concerned the dynamics of interacting flapping swimmers, with a view to modeling schooling and flocking behavior in animal collectives. Schools of fish and flocks of birds are archetypical examples of animal collectives that interact through high-speed flows, where theoretical understanding is rather limited. Most models of such collectives emphasize the behavior of the constituents, positing interaction laws but neglecting the fluid medium through which they move. A goal of the PI's research program is to use model systems to understand how hydrodynamics can mediate schooling behavior. To that end, the PI considered a one-dimensional "flock" of flapping swimmers in water. This system was realized experimentally using wings in a cylindrical water tank that are driven periodically in the vertical direction by a motor. Each wing swims into the wake generated by the other, and is free to choose both its position and speed. The PI constructed a theoretical model with the goal of quantitatively understanding the hydrodynamic interactions between swimmers generating high-speed flows.

The PI's collaborative study is the first to demonstrate experimentally that hydrodynamic interactions alone can lead to ordered formations in flapping flight. While biologists, physicists and mathematicians have long suspected that hydrodynamic interactions may lead to more efficient swimming or flying in dense animal collectives, the role of hydrodynamics in mediating schooling or flocking behavior has remained unknown. The PI's research has inspired further experimental and theoretical studies aimed at characterizing the flow-induced interactions between flapping swimmers in more complicated settings.

The third project concerned the collective dynamics of active liquid crystals. The self-organization principles that govern the dynamics of complex cellular structures are largely unknown, making clear the need for simplified model systems amenable to mathematical modeling and analysis. An example is the remarkable system constructed by Zvonimir Dogic and colleagues, who demonstrated that collections of microtubule filaments, coupled with molecular motors and immersed in a fluid, may self organize into an active liquid crystal and generate spatiotemporally complex flows. These pioneering experiments have generated considerable interest from physicists and biologists, as the active liquid crystal system comprises a relatively simple experimental archetype for microscale cellular dynamics and fluid flows. The PI constructed and analyzed a model for this system, and quantitatively compared its predictions with experimental data. The model exhibited good agreement with experiment and thus could be used to model the ordering processes in cellular systems of greater complexity.

The PI's research has presented opportunities for outreach to the broader public. For example, the PI's work on orbital bound states of walking droplets was featured on the American Physical Society's Physics Central webpage, a portal designed to convey the importance and excitement of physics research to the general public. The PI also spoke about his research at cSplash, an annual event aimed at mathematically-inclined high school students in the New York metropolitan area.

The PI has also maintained an ongoing commitment to mentoring international and underrepresented minority students in research. Two students were initially mentored as visiting interns, and then gained admission as PhD candidates in the Department of Mathematics at MIT. Another student was a Masters' student from France and is currently a doctoral student. All three research projects resulted in publications.
